context: A gear is a rotating circular machine part having cut teeth or, in the case of a cogwheel or gearwheel, inserted teeth (called cogs), which mesh with another toothed part to transmit torque.
question: A toothed wheel that works with others to alter the relation between the speed of a driving mechanism and the speed of the driven parts.

context: A bearing is a machine element that constrains relative motion to only the desired motion, and reduces friction between moving parts.
question: A machine element that reduces friction between moving parts.

context: An internal combustion engine is a heat engine in which the combustion of a fuel occurs with an oxidizer (usually air) in a combustion chamber that is an integral part of the working ﬂuid ﬂow circuit.
question: An engine that generates power by burning fuel within the engine itself.

context: A four-stroke engine is an internal combustion engine in which the piston completes four separate strokes while turning the crankshaft. A stroke refers to the full travel of the piston along the cylinder, in either direction.
question: An engine with four piston strokes: intake, compression, combustion, and exhaust.

context: A jet engine is a type of reaction engine discharging a fast-moving jet that generates thrust by jet propulsion.
question: An engine that generates thrust by expelling a fast-moving jet of fluid.

context: HVAC stands for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning. It is the technology of indoor and vehicular environmental comfort.
question: What does HVAC stand for?

context: A CAD (Computer-Aided Design) system is a software tool used by engineers and designers to create precision drawings or technical illustrations in two-dimensional (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) models.
question: Software used by engineers to create 2D and 3D models.

context: Finite Element Analysis (FEA) is a computerized method for predicting how a product reacts to real-world forces, vibration, heat, ﬂuid ﬂow, and other physical eﬀects.
question: A computerized method for predicting how a product reacts to real-world forces.

context: A prototype is an early sample, model, or release of a product built to test a concept or process.
question: An early sample or model of a product built for testing.

context: Reverse engineering is the process of extracting knowledge or design information from a product and reproducing it or reproducing anything based on the extracted information.
question: The process of deconstructing a product to understand how it works.

context: A patent is a type of intellectual property that gives its owner the legal right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention for a limited period of years.
question: A form of intellectual property that protects an invention.

context: A trademark is a recognizable sign, design, or expression which identiﬁes products or services of a particular source from those of others.
question: A recognizable sign or design that identifies a product or service.

context: A copyright is a legal right that grants the creator of an original work exclusive rights for its use and distribution.
question: A legal right that protects an original work of authorship.

context: Project management is the practice of initiating, planning, executing, controlling, and closing the work of a team to achieve speciﬁc goals and meet speciﬁc success criteria at the speciﬁed time.
question: The practice of planning, executing, and controlling the work of a team to achieve specific goals.

context: A Gantt chart is a type of bar chart that illustrates a project schedule. --- Project Plan --- It illustrates the start and ﬁnish dates of the terminal elements and summary elements of a project.
question: A bar chart used to illustrate a project schedule.

context: The critical path method (CPM) is an algorithm for scheduling a set of project activities. It identiﬁes the longest stretch of dependent tasks and measures the time required to complete them from start to ﬁnish.
question: A project management algorithm for identifying the longest sequence of dependent tasks.

context: Quality control (QC) is a process by which entities review the quality of all factors involved in production.
question: The process of reviewing the quality of all factors involved in production.

context: Quality assurance (QA) is the maintenance of a desired level of quality in a service or product, especially by means of attention to every stage of the process of delivery or production.
question: A way of preventing mistakes or defects in manufactured products and avoiding problems when delivering solutions or services.

context: Six Sigma is a set of techniques and tools for process improvement. It seeks to improve the quality of the output of a process by identifying and removing the causes of defects and minimizing variability.
question: A set of techniques and tools for process improvement, aiming to reduce defects.

context: Lean manufacturing is a production method aimed primarily at reducing times within the production system as well as response times from suppliers and to customers.
question: A production method focused on minimizing waste and maximizing productivity.

context: Just-in-time (JIT) manufacturing is a methodology aimed primarily at reducing times within the production system as well as response times from suppliers and to customers.
question: A manufacturing strategy where materials are ordered and received only as they are needed in the production process.

context: Ergonomics is the process of designing or arranging workplaces, products and systems so that they ﬁt the people who use them.
question: The science of designing and arranging things people use so that the people and things interact most efficiently and safely.

context: A kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a measure of electrical energy equivalent to a power consumption of one thousand watts for one hour.
question: A common unit of electrical energy.

context: Horsepower (hp) is a unit of measurement of power, or the rate at which work is done.
question: A unit of power, often used to measure the output of engines.

context: The pH scale is a scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution.
question: A scale used to measure acidity or basicity.

context: A mole is the unit of amount of substance in the International System of Units (SI). It is deﬁned as exactly 6.02214076×10²³ particles.
question: The SI unit for the amount of a substance.

context: Avogadro's number is the number of constituent particles, usually atoms or molecules, that are contained in the amount of substance given by one mole. It is approximately 6.022×10²³.
question: The number of particles in one mole of a substance.

context: A schematic diagram is a representation of the elements of a system using abstract, graphic symbols rather than realistic pictures. A schematic usually omits all details that are not relevant to the information the schematic is intended to convey.
question: A diagram that represents the elements of a system using abstract symbols.

context: A blueprint is a reproduction of a technical drawing or engineering drawing using a contact print process on light-sensitive sheets.
question: A design plan or other technical drawing.

context: A sensor is a device, module, machine, or subsystem whose purpose is to detect events or changes in its environment and send the information to other electronics, frequently a computer processor.
question: A device that detects changes in its environment and sends the information to a computer.

context: An actuator is a component of a machine that is responsible for moving and controlling a mechanism or system, for example by opening a valve. In simple terms, it is a 'mover'.
question: A component of a machine that is responsible for moving and controlling a mechanism.

context: A microcontroller is a small computer on a single integrated circuit. It contains a processor core, memory, and programmable input/output peripherals.
question: A small computer on a single integrated circuit.

context: A Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) is an industrial digital computer which has been ruggedized and adapted for the control of manufacturing processes, such as assembly lines, or robotic devices.
question: An industrial computer used to control manufacturing processes.

context: A feedback control system is a control system which tends to maintain a relationship of one system variable to another by comparing the value of the controlled variable with a desired value and using the diﬀerence as a means of control.
question: A control system that uses the output of a system to control its input.

context: An open-loop controller, also called a non-feedback controller, is a type of controller that computes its input into a system using only the current state and its model of the system.
question: A control system that does not use feedback to adjust its output.

context: A bandwidth, in signal processing, is the diﬀerence between the upper and lower frequencies in a continuous set of frequencies.
question: The range of frequencies within a given band.

context: A signal is a function that conveys information about a phenomenon. In electronics and telecommunications, it refers to any time-varying voltage, current, or electromagnetic wave that carries information.
question: A function that conveys information.

context: An analog signal is a continuous signal in which one time-varying quantity represents another time-based variable.
question: A continuous signal that represents a physical measurement.

context: A digital signal is a signal that is constructed from a discrete set of waveforms of a physical quantity so as to represent a sequence of discrete values.
question: A signal that is represented by a sequence of discrete values.

context: The Nyquist rate is the minimum sampling rate required to avoid aliasing, equal to twice the highest frequency present in the signal.
question: The minimum sampling rate required to perfectly reconstruct a signal.

context: A Fourier transform is a mathematical transform that decomposes a function (often a function of time, or a signal) into its constituent frequencies.
question: A mathematical transform that decomposes a signal into its constituent frequencies.

context: A filter is a device or process that removes some unwanted components or features from a signal.
question: A device that removes unwanted frequencies from a signal.

context: A low-pass ﬁlter is a ﬁlter that passes signals with a frequency lower than a selected cutoﬀ frequency and attenuates signals with frequencies higher than the cutoﬀ frequency.
question: A filter that passes low-frequency signals and blocks high-frequency signals.

context: A high-pass ﬁlter is a ﬁlter that passes signals with a frequency higher than a certain cutoﬀ frequency and attenuates signals with frequencies lower than the cutoﬀ frequency.
question: A filter that passes high-frequency signals and blocks low-frequency signals.

context: A band-pass ﬁlter is a device that passes frequencies within a certain range and rejects (attenuates) frequencies outside that range.
question: A filter that passes frequencies within a specific range.

context: An amplifier is an electronic device that can increase the power of a signal.
question: An electronic device that increases the power of a signal.

context: An oscillator is an electronic circuit that produces a periodic, oscillating electronic signal, often a sine wave or a square wave.
question: An electronic circuit that produces a periodic, oscillating signal.

context: A power supply is an electrical device that supplies electric power to an electrical load.
question: A device that supplies electric power to a load.

context: A battery is a device consisting of one or more electrochemical cells with external connections for powering electrical devices.
question: A device that converts chemical energy into electrical energy.

context: A solar cell, or photovoltaic cell, is an electrical device that converts the energy of light directly into electricity by the photovoltaic eﬀect.
question: A device that converts light energy into electricity.

context: A fuel cell is an electrochemical cell that converts the chemical energy of a fuel (often hydrogen) and an oxidizing agent (often oxygen) into electricity through a pair of redox reactions.
question: A device that converts chemical energy from a fuel into electricity.

context: A renewable energy source is an energy source that is naturally replenished on a human timescale, such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat.
question: An energy source that is naturally replenished.

context: A non-renewable energy source is a natural resource that cannot be readily replaced by natural means at a quick enough pace to keep up with consumption. Fossil fuels like oil, natural gas, and coal are examples.
question: An energy source that cannot be readily replaced, like fossil fuels.

context: Fossil fuels are fuels formed by natural processes, such as anaerobic decomposition of buried dead organisms, containing organic matter, originating in the ancient past.
question: Fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas, formed from the remains of ancient organisms.

context: Nuclear power is the use of nuclear reactions that release nuclear energy to generate heat, which most frequently is then used in steam turbines to produce electricity in a nuclear power plant.
question: The use of nuclear reactions to generate electricity.

context: Nuclear ﬁssion is a nuclear reaction in which the nucleus of an atom splits into smaller parts (lighter nuclei), often producing free neutrons and photons (in the form of gamma rays), and releasing a very large amount of energy.
question: A nuclear reaction where an atom's nucleus splits into smaller parts.

context: Nuclear fusion is a reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei are combined to form one or more diﬀerent atomic nuclei and subatomic particles (neutrons or protons).
question: A nuclear reaction where two or more atomic nuclei combine.

context: A blockchain is a growing list of records, called blocks, that are linked using cryptography.
question: A distributed, immutable ledger of records called blocks.

context: Artiﬁcial intelligence (AI) is intelligence demonstrated by machines, unlike the natural intelligence displayed by humans and animals.
question: Intelligence demonstrated by machines.

context: Machine learning is the study of computer algorithms that can improve automatically through experience and by the use of data.
question: A field of AI where algorithms improve through experience and data.

context: A neural network is a network or circuit of neurons, or in a modern sense, an artiﬁcial neural network, composed of artiﬁcial neurons or nodes.
question: A computing system inspired by the biological neural networks that constitute animal brains.

context: Deep learning is part of a broader family of machine learning methods based on artiﬁcial neural networks with representation learning.
question: A type of machine learning based on artificial neural networks with many layers.

context: The Internet of Things (IoT) describes the network of physical objects—'things'—that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the Internet.
question: The network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software to connect and exchange data.

context: Cybersecurity is the practice of defending computers, servers, mobile devices, electronic systems, networks, and data from malicious attacks.
question: The practice of protecting computer systems and networks from digital attacks.

context: Malware, short for 'malicious software', is any software intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
question: Software intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer system.

context: A virus is a type of computer program that, when executed, replicates itself by modifying other computer programs and inserting its own code.
question: A type of malware that replicates itself by infecting other programs.

context: Ransomware is a type of malware that threatens to publish the victim's data or perpetually block access to it unless a ransom is paid.
question: Malware that encrypts a victim's files and demands payment for their release.

context: Phishing is a type of social engineering attack often used to steal user data, including login credentials and credit card numbers.
question: An attack where fraudulent emails are sent to trick users into revealing sensitive information.

context: A ﬁrewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traﬃc based on predetermined security rules.
question: A network security system that monitors and controls network traffic.

context: Encryption is the process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.
question: The process of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.

context: A VPN, or Virtual Private Network, extends a private network across a public network and enables users to send and receive data across shared or public networks as if their computing devices were directly connected to the private network.
question: A service that creates a secure, encrypted connection over a public network.

context: A digital signature is a mathematical scheme for verifying the authenticity of digital messages or documents.
question: A mathematical scheme for verifying the authenticity of a digital document.

context: Biometrics are body measurements and calculations related to human characteristics. Biometric authentication is used in computer science as a form of identiﬁcation and access control.
question: Authentication using unique physical characteristics, like fingerprints or facial recognition.

context: Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) is a security process where users provide two diﬀerent authentication factors to verify themselves.
question: A security process requiring two different forms of identification.

context: Aerospace engineering is the primary ﬁeld of engineering concerned with the development of aircraft and spacecraft.
question: The engineering field concerned with aircraft and spacecraft.

context: Aerodynamics is the study of the properties of moving air and the interaction between the air and solid bodies moving through it.
question: The study of how air moves around objects.

context: Lift is the component of the aerodynamic force that is perpendicular to the oncoming ﬂow direction. It contrasts with the drag force, which is parallel to the ﬂow direction.
question: The aerodynamic force that acts perpendicular to the direction of motion, keeping an aircraft in the air.

context: Drag is a mechanical force generated by the interaction and contact of a solid body with a ﬂuid (liquid or gas). It is the force that opposes an aircraft's motion.
question: The aerodynamic force that opposes an aircraft's motion.

context: Thrust is the force which moves an aircraft through the air. Thrust is generated by the propulsion system of the aircraft.
question: The forward-acting force generated by an aircraft's propulsion system.

context: The four forces of ﬂight are lift, weight, thrust, and drag.
question: What are the four primary forces acting on an aircraft in flight?

context: An airfoil is the cross-sectional shape of a wing, blade (of a propeller, rotor, or turbine), or sail (as seen in cross-section).
question: The cross-sectional shape of a wing.

context: The sound barrier is the large increase in aerodynamic drag that occurs as an aircraft approaches the speed of sound.
question: The point at which an aircraft matches the speed of sound.

context: The Mach number is a dimensionless quantity in ﬂuid dynamics representing the ratio of ﬂow velocity past a boundary to the local speed of sound.
question: The ratio of an object's speed to the speed of sound.

context: Orbital mechanics or astrodynamics is the application of ballistics and celestial mechanics to the practical problems concerning the motion of rockets and other spacecraft.
question: The study of the motion of spacecraft and rockets.

context: Escape velocity is the minimum speed needed for a free, non-propelled object to escape from the gravitational inﬂuence of a massive body.
question: The minimum speed required for an object to escape the gravitational pull of a planet.

context: A satellite is an artiﬁcial object which has been intentionally placed into orbit.
question: An artificial object placed into orbit around a celestial body.

context: A rocket engine uses stored rocket propellant as the reaction mass for forming a high-speed propulsive jet of ﬂuid, usually high-temperature gas.
question: An engine that produces thrust by expelling high-speed exhaust from a propellant.

context: Biomedical engineering is the application of engineering principles and design concepts to medicine and biology for healthcare purposes.
question: The application of engineering principles to medicine and biology.

context: Biomechanics is the study of the structure, function and motion of the mechanical aspects of biological systems, at any level from whole organisms to organs, cells and cell organelles, using the methods of mechanics.
question: The study of the mechanical aspects of biological systems.

context: A prosthesis is an artiﬁcial device that replaces a missing body part, which may be lost through trauma, disease, or a condition present at birth.
question: An artificial device that replaces a missing body part.

context: Tissue engineering is the use of a combination of cells, engineering, and materials methods, and suitable biochemical and physicochemical factors to improve or replace biological tissues.
question: The use of cells and materials to restore or replace biological tissues.

context: A bioreactor provides a biologically active environment to support the growth of cells or tissues in tissue engineering.
question: A device that supports a biologically active environment for growing cells or tissues.

context: A medical implant is a medical device manufactured to replace a missing biological structure, support a damaged biological structure, or enhance an existing biological structure.
question: A device placed inside the body to replace or support a biological structure.

context: Biocompatibility is the property of a material being compatible with living tissue. Biocompatible materials do not produce a toxic or immunological response when exposed to the body.
question: The property of a material being compatible with living tissue.

context: An electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the heartbeat.
question: A test that measures the electrical activity of the heart.

context: An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a test that detects electrical activity in your brain using small, metal discs (electrodes) attached to your scalp.
question: A test that detects electrical activity in the brain.

context: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a medical imaging technique used in radiology to form pictures of the anatomy and the physiological processes of the body.
question: An imaging technique using magnetic fields to create detailed images of the body.

context: A pacemaker is a medical device that generates electrical impulses delivered by electrodes to contract the heart muscles and regulate the electrical conduction system of the heart.
question: A medical device that regulates the heartbeat.

context: Dialysis is a process for removing waste and excess water from the blood and is used primarily as an artiﬁcial replacement for lost kidney function.
question: A procedure to remove waste from the blood when kidneys fail.

context: Software engineering is the systematic application of engineering principles to the development of software.
question: The application of engineering principles to software development.

context: The software development life cycle (SDLC) is a process for planning, creating, testing, and deploying an information system.
question: A process for planning, creating, testing, and deploying software.

context: The waterfall model is a sequential design process, used in software development processes, in which progress is seen as ﬂowing steadily downwards (like a waterfall) through the phases of conception, initiation, analysis, design, construction, testing, deployment and maintenance.
question: A sequential software development model where each phase must be completed before the next begins.

context: Agile software development comprises various approaches to software development under which requirements and solutions evolve through the collaborative eﬀort of self-organizing and cross-functional teams and their customer(s)/end user(s).
question: An iterative approach to software development focused on collaboration and flexibility.

context: Scrum is an agile framework for managing knowledge work, with an emphasis on software development.
question: An agile framework for managing projects, often used in software development.

context: A sprint is a set period of time during which speciﬁc work has to be completed and made ready for review. It is a core concept in the Scrum framework.
question: A short, time-boxed period in Scrum during which a team works to complete a set amount of work.

context: Version control is the practice of tracking and managing changes to software code. Version control systems are software tools that help software teams manage changes to source code over time.
question: The practice of tracking and managing changes to software code.

context: Git is a distributed version-control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
question: A popular distributed version control system.

context: A repository is a central location in which data is stored and managed. In Git, a repository contains all of the project's ﬁles and the entire revision history.
question: A central location where code and its revision history are stored in version control.

context: DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops). It aims to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality.
question: A set of practices that combines software development and IT operations.

context: Continuous Integration (CI) is the practice of merging all developers' working copies to a shared mainline several times a day.
question: The practice of frequently merging developers' code changes into a central repository.

context: Continuous Delivery (CD) is a software engineering approach in which teams produce software in short cycles, ensuring that the software can be reliably released at any time.
question: An approach where software can be reliably released at any time.

context: Unit testing is a software testing method by which individual units of source code are tested to determine whether they are ﬁt for use.
question: Testing individual components or units of source code.

context: Integration testing is the phase in software testing in which individual software modules are combined and tested as a group.
question: Testing how different software modules work together as a group.

context: An Application Programming Interface (API) is a computing interface which deﬁnes interactions between multiple software intermediaries.
question: A set of rules and tools for building software and applications, defining how different software components should interact.

context: Environmental engineering is a professional engineering discipline that takes from broad scientiﬁc topics like chemistry, biology, ecology, geology, hydraulics, hydrology, microbiology, and mathematics to create solutions that will protect and also improve the health of living organisms and improve the quality of the environment.
question: The branch of engineering focused on protecting the environment and improving public health.

context: Water treatment is any process that improves the quality of water to make it appropriate for a speciﬁc end-use.
question: The process of improving water quality for a specific use, like drinking.

context: Wastewater treatment is a process used to remove contaminants from wastewater or sewage and convert it into an eﬄuent that can be returned to the water cycle with minimum impact on the environment.
question: The process of removing contaminants from sewage and wastewater.

context: A pollutant is a substance or energy introduced into the environment that has undesired eﬀects, or adversely aﬀects the usefulness of a resource.
question: A substance that has harmful effects on the environment.

context: Air pollution is the presence of substances in the atmosphere that are harmful to the health of humans and other living beings, or cause damage to the climate or to materials.
question: The presence of harmful substances in the atmosphere.

context: The greenhouse eﬀect is the process by which radiation from a planet's atmosphere warms the planet's surface to a temperature above what it would be without this atmosphere.
question: The process where atmospheric gases trap heat and warm a planet's surface.

context: Acid rain is a rain or any other form of precipitation that is unusually acidic, meaning that it has elevated levels of hydrogen ions.
question: Rain that is unusually acidic due to atmospheric pollution.

context: A landﬁll site is a site for the disposal of waste materials by burial.
question: A site for disposing of waste by burying it.

context: Recycling is the process of converting waste materials into new materials and objects.
question: The process of converting waste into reusable material.

context: Sustainability is the ability to exist constantly. In the 21st century, it refers generally to the capacity for the biosphere and human civilization to coexist.
question: Meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

context: A carbon footprint is the total amount of greenhouse gases (including carbon dioxide and methane) that are generated by our actions.
question: The total amount of greenhouse gases generated by a person's actions.

context: Robotics is an interdisciplinary branch of engineering and science that includes mechanical engineering, electronic engineering, information engineering, computer science, and others. Robotics deals with the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.
question: The branch of engineering dealing with the design, construction, and operation of robots.

context: An end eﬀector is the device at the end of a robotic arm, designed to interact with the environment.
question: The device at the end of a robotic arm that interacts with the environment.

context: Kinematics is a branch of classical mechanics that describes the motion of points, bodies (objects), and systems of bodies (groups of objects) without considering the forces that cause them to move.
question: The study of motion without considering the forces that cause it.

context: Degrees of freedom (DOF) of a mechanical system is the number of independent parameters that deﬁne its conﬁguration or state.
question: The number of independent parameters that define the configuration of a mechanical system.

context: An autonomous robot is a robot that performs behaviors or tasks with a high degree of autonomy, which is particularly desirable in ﬁelds such as spaceﬂight, household maintenance, and delivering goods and services.
question: A robot that can perform tasks without human control.

context: Computer vision is an interdisciplinary scientiﬁc ﬁeld that deals with how computers can gain high-level understanding from digital images or videos.
question: The field of AI that enables computers to 'see' and interpret visual information from the world.

context: LIDAR is a method for measuring distances by illuminating the target with laser light and measuring the reﬂection with a sensor.
question: A remote sensing method that uses laser light to measure distances.

context: Nanotechnology is the manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale.
question: The manipulation of matter on an atomic and molecular scale.

context: A nanomaterial is a material with any external dimension in the nanoscale or having internal structure or surface structure in the nanoscale.
question: A material with at least one dimension in the 1-100 nanometer range.

context: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation.
question: A type of computing that uses quantum-mechanical phenomena like superposition.

context: A qubit or quantum bit is the basic unit of quantum information—the quantum version of the classical binary bit.
question: The basic unit of quantum information.

context: A 3D printer is a machine allowing the creation of a physical object from a three-dimensional digital model, typically by laying down many thin layers of a material in succession.
question: A machine that creates physical objects from a digital model by additive manufacturing.

context: Additive manufacturing, also known as 3D printing, is a transformative approach to industrial production that enables the creation of lighter, stronger parts and systems.
question: The process of creating an object by building it one layer at a time.

context: Subtractive manufacturing is a process by which 3D objects are constructed by successively cutting material away from a solid block of material.
question: A manufacturing process where material is removed from a larger piece to create a part.

context: A CNC machine, or Computer Numerical Control machine, is a machine tool that uses computers to control machine tools.
question: A machine that uses computer control to operate tools like lathes and mills.

context: A lathe is a machine tool that rotates a workpiece about an axis of rotation to perform various operations such as cutting, sanding, knurling, drilling, deformation, facing, and turning.
question: A machine tool that rotates a workpiece to perform various operations.

context: A milling machine is a machine tool that removes material from a workpiece by rotating a cutting tool.
question: A machine tool that uses a rotating cutter to remove material from a workpiece.

context: Welding is a fabrication process that joins materials, usually metals or thermoplastics, by using high heat to melt the parts together and allowing them to cool, causing fusion.
question: A process that joins materials by melting them together.

context: Soldering is a process in which two or more items are joined together by melting and putting a ﬁller metal (solder) into the joint, the ﬁller metal having a lower melting point than the adjoining metal.
question: A process of joining metals using a filler metal with a low melting point.

context: A patent troll is a person or company that attempts to enforce patent rights against accused infringers far beyond the patent's actual value or contribution.
question: A person or company that enforces patents against infringers in an aggressive or opportunistic manner.

context: A trade secret is a formula, practice, process, design, instrument, pattern, or compilation of information which is not generally known or reasonably ascertainable, by which a business can obtain an economic advantage over competitors or customers.
question: Confidential business information that gives a competitive edge.

context: An industrial engineer is a professional who is concerned with the optimization of complex processes, systems, or organizations by developing, improving and implementing integrated systems of people, money, knowledge, information, equipment, energy and materials.
question: An engineer who focuses on optimizing complex processes and systems.

context: A supply chain is a system of organizations, people, activities, information, and resources involved in moving a product or service from supplier to customer.
question: A system of organizations and resources involved in moving a product from supplier to customer.

context: Logistics is the management of the ﬂow of things between the point of origin and the point of consumption in order to meet requirements of customers or corporations.
question: The management of the flow of goods between the point of origin and consumption.

context: A bill of materials (BOM) is a comprehensive list of raw materials, components, and assemblies required to construct, manufacture or repair a product.
question: A list of all the raw materials and components needed to manufacture a product.

context: A system is a group of interacting or interrelated entities that form a uniﬁed whole. A system is delineated by its spatial and temporal boundaries, surrounded and inﬂuenced by its environment, described by its structure and purpose and expressed in its functioning.
question: A group of interacting entities that form a unified whole.

context: Systems engineering is an interdisciplinary ﬁeld of engineering and engineering management that focuses on how to design and manage complex systems over their life cycles.
question: An engineering field focused on designing and managing complex systems.

context: A requirement is a condition or capability needed by a user to solve a problem or achieve an objective. --- Project Speciﬁcations --- In engineering, requirements are the needs that a new or altered product must meet.
question: In engineering, a condition or capability that a new product must meet.

context: Veriﬁcation is the process of checking that a software system meets speciﬁcations.
question: The process of checking if a system meets its specifications.

context: Validation is the process of checking whether the speciﬁcation captures the customer’s needs.
question: The process of checking if a system meets the customer's actual needs.

context: The V-model is a graphical representation of a systems development lifecycle. It is used to produce rigorous development lifecycle models and project management models.
question: A systems development model that represents verification and validation phases for each development stage.

context: A stakeholder is a person with an interest or concern in something, especially a business.
question: A person or group with an interest or concern in a project or system.

context: A trade study is the activity of identifying a balanced solution among a set of candidate solutions.
question: The process of comparing and evaluating alternative solutions to a problem.

context: A model is a representation of a system, used to understand, predict, and control its behavior.
question: A representation of a system used to understand its behavior.

context: A simulation is the imitation of the operation of a real-world process or system over time.
question: The imitation of a real-world process or system over time.

context: A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.
question: A system that manages or regulates the behavior of other systems.

context: A sensor is a device that measures a physical quantity and converts it into a signal which can be read by an observer or by an instrument.
question: A device that measures a physical quantity and converts it into a signal.

context: An actuator is a component of a machine that is responsible for moving and controlling a mechanism or system.
question: A component that is responsible for moving or controlling a mechanism.

context: A transducer is a device that converts energy from one form to another. Usually a transducer converts a signal in one form of energy to a signal in another.
question: A device that converts energy from one form to another.

context: A thermocouple is a sensor for measuring temperature. It consists of two diﬀerent types of metals, joined together at one end.
question: A temperature sensor made of two different metals joined together.

context: A strain gauge is a sensor whose resistance varies with applied force; It converts force, pressure, tension, weight, etc., into a change in electrical resistance which can then be measured.
question: A sensor used to measure strain on an object.

context: An accelerometer is a tool that measures proper acceleration. Proper acceleration is the acceleration (the rate of change of velocity) of a body in its own instantaneous rest frame.
question: A device that measures acceleration.

context: A gyroscope is a device used for measuring or maintaining orientation and angular velocity.
question: A device for measuring or maintaining orientation and angular velocity.

context: An Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) is an electronic device that measures and reports a body's speciﬁc force, angular rate, and sometimes the orientation of the body, using a combination of accelerometers, gyroscopes, and sometimes magnetometers.
question: A device that measures a body's specific force and angular rate using accelerometers and gyroscopes.

context: A Kalman ﬁlter is an algorithm that uses a series of measurements observed over time, containing statistical noise and other inaccuracies, and produces estimates of unknown variables that tend to be more accurate than those based on a single measurement alone.
question: An algorithm used to produce optimal estimates of a system's state from a series of noisy measurements.

context: A redundant system is a system which has duplicate or backup components to improve reliability.
question: A system with backup components to improve reliability.

context: Failure mode and eﬀects analysis (FMEA) is the process of reviewing as many components, assemblies, and subsystems as possible to identify potential failure modes in a system and their causes and eﬀects.
question: A process for identifying potential failure modes in a system.

context: Root cause analysis (RCA) is a method of problem solving used for identifying the root causes of faults or problems.
question: A method of problem solving used to identify the fundamental cause of a fault.

context: A fault tree analysis (FTA) is a top-down, deductive failure analysis in which an undesired state of a system is analyzed using Boolean logic to combine a series of lower-level events.
question: A top-down failure analysis that uses Boolean logic to trace an undesired state back to its causes.

context: A patent is a form of intellectual property. A patent gives its owner the right to exclude others from making, using, selling, and importing an invention for a limited period of time, usually twenty years.
question: A legal right granted for an invention.

context: A standard is an established norm or requirement about technical systems. It is a formal document that establishes uniform engineering or technical criteria, methods, processes, and practices.
question: A formal document that establishes uniform engineering or technical criteria.

context: The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an international standard-setting body composed of representatives from various national standards organizations.
question: An international body that develops and publishes standards.

context: ISO 9001 is a standard that sets out the requirements for a quality management system.
question: An international standard for a quality management system.

context: The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) is an international standards organization that develops and publishes voluntary consensus technical standards for a wide range of materials, products, systems, and services.
question: An organization that develops technical standards for materials and products.
answer: The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM)

context: The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) is a professional association for electronic engineering and electrical engineering with its corporate oﬃce in New York City and its operations center in Piscataway, New Jersey.
question: A professional association for electronic and electrical engineering.
answer: The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)

context: A professional engineer (PE) is a person licensed by a state board of registration to practice engineering.
question: A person who is licensed to practice engineering.

context: The Order of the Engineer is an association for graduate and professional engineers in the United States that emphasizes pride and responsibility in the engineering profession. To be initiated, engineers take an oath and receive a stainless steel ring to be worn on the little ﬁnger of the working hand.
question: An association for engineers in the U.S. where members take an oath and wear a steel ring.

context: The engineering design process is a common series of steps that engineers use in creating functional products and processes.
question: A series of steps engineers use to create products and processes.

context: A Pugh chart is a qualitative technique used to rank the multi-dimensional options of an option set. It is a criteria-based matrix.
question: A criteria-based matrix used to rank a set of design options.

context: A proof of concept (PoC) is a realization of a certain method or idea in order to demonstrate its feasibility, or a demonstration in principle with the aim of verifying that some concept or theory has practical potential.
question: A demonstration to verify that a concept or theory has practical potential.

context: A breadboard is a construction base for prototyping of electronics.
question: A base used for prototyping electronic circuits.

context: A minimum viable product (MVP) is a version of a product with just enough features to be usable by early customers who can then provide feedback for future product development.
question: A version of a new product which allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort.

context: A design review is a milestone within a product development process whereby a design is evaluated against its requirements in order to verify the outcomes of previous activities and identify issues before committing to—and wasting eﬀort in—further work.
question: A formal meeting to evaluate a design against its requirements.

context: A tolerance is the permissible limit or limits of variation in a physical dimension, a measured value or physical property of a material, manufactured object, system, or service.
question: The permissible limit of variation in a physical dimension.

context: Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing (GD&T) is a system for deﬁning and communicating engineering tolerances.
question: A system for defining and communicating engineering tolerances on drawings.

context: A case study is a research method involving an up-close, in-depth, and detailed examination of a subject of study (the case), as well as its related contextual conditions.
question: An in-depth examination of a specific subject or event.

context: Ethics in engineering is the ﬁeld of applied ethics and system of moral principles that apply to the practice of engineering.
question: The system of moral principles that apply to the practice of engineering.

context: A conﬂict of interest is a situation in which a person or organization is involved in multiple interests, ﬁnancial or otherwise, and serving one interest could involve working against another.
question: A situation where a person's private interests could improperly influence their professional duties.

context: A whistleblower is a person who exposes any kind of information or activity that is deemed illegal, unethical, or not correct within an organization.
question: A person who exposes misconduct or illegal activity within an organization.

context: The Challenger disaster was a fatal accident in 1986 in the United States' space program in which the Space Shuttle Challenger broke apart 73 seconds into its ﬂight, killing all seven crew members. The disaster was caused by the failure of an O-ring seal in its right solid rocket booster.
question: What 1986 space shuttle disaster was caused by an O-ring failure?

context: The Chernobyl disaster was a nuclear accident that occurred in 1986 at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine. It is considered the worst nuclear disaster in history.
question: What 1986 nuclear accident is considered the worst in history?

context: The Tacoma Narrows Bridge was a suspension bridge in Washington that collapsed in 1940. The bridge's collapse was due to aeroelastic ﬂutter.
question: What famous bridge collapsed in 1940 due to aeroelastic flutter?

context: Aeroelastic ﬂutter is a dynamic instability of an elastic structure in a ﬂuid ﬂow, caused by positive feedback between the body's deﬂection and the force exerted by the ﬂuid ﬂow.
question: A dynamic instability of a structure in a fluid flow, which caused the Tacoma Narrows Bridge to collapse.

context: A black box is a device, system, or object which can be viewed in terms of its inputs and outputs, without any knowledge of its internal workings.
question: A device or system that can be viewed in terms of its inputs and outputs without knowledge of its internal workings.

context: A ﬂight recorder, colloquially known as a black box, is an electronic recording device placed in an aircraft for the purpose of facilitating the investigation of aviation accidents and incidents.
question: A recording device placed in an aircraft to help investigate accidents.

context: A user interface (UI) is the space where interactions between humans and machines occur.
question: The space where interactions between humans and machines occur.

context: User experience (UX) is a person's emotions and attitudes about using a particular product, system or service.
question: A person's emotions and attitudes about using a particular product or system.

context: A speciﬁcation is an explicit set of requirements to be satisﬁed by a material, design, product, or service.
question: An explicit set of requirements for a material, design, or product.

context: A constraint is a limitation or restriction. In engineering design, constraints are the limitations and restrictions a design must adhere to.
question: A limitation or restriction that a design must adhere to.

context: Optimization is the selection of a best element (with regard to some criterion) from some set of available alternatives.
question: The process of finding the best solution from a set of alternatives.

context: A trade-oﬀ is a situational decision that involves diminishing or losing one quality, quantity, or property of a set or design in return for gains in other aspects.
question: A design choice that involves losing one quality in return for gains in another.

context: A life-cycle assessment (LCA) is a methodology for assessing environmental impacts associated with all the stages of the life-cycle of a commercial product, process, or service.
question: A methodology for assessing the environmental impacts of a product's entire life cycle.

context: Cradle-to-grave is the full Life Cycle Assessment from resource extraction ('cradle') to use phase and disposal phase ('grave').
question: An assessment of a product's life cycle from resource extraction to disposal.

context: Cradle-to-cradle design is a biomimetic approach to the design of products and systems. It models human industry on nature's processes, where materials are viewed as nutrients circulating in healthy, safe metabolisms.
question: A design philosophy that models human industry on nature's processes, aiming for materials to be reused or recycled.

context: Biomimicry is the imitation of the models, systems, and elements of nature for the purpose of solving complex human problems.
question: The imitation of nature's models and systems to solve human problems.

context: A free body diagram is a graphical illustration used to visualize the applied forces, moments, and resulting reactions on a body in a given condition.
question: A diagram used to visualize all the forces acting on a body.

context: A moment of inertia is a quantity expressing a body's tendency to resist angular acceleration. It is the sum of the products of the mass of each particle in the body with the square of its distance from the axis of rotation.
question: A quantity that measures a body's resistance to angular acceleration.

context: The center of mass of a distribution of mass in space is the unique point where the weighted relative position of the distributed mass sums to zero.
question: The unique point where the weighted relative position of an object's mass sums to zero.

context: A pressure vessel is a container designed to hold gases or liquids at a pressure substantially diﬀerent from the ambient pressure.
question: A container designed to hold gases or liquids at high pressure.

context: A boiler is a closed vessel in which ﬂuid (generally water) is heated. The ﬂuid does not necessarily boil.
question: A closed vessel in which a fluid is heated.

context: A heat sink is a passive heat exchanger that transfers the heat generated by an electronic or a mechanical device to a ﬂuid medium, often air or a liquid coolant, where it is dissipated away from the device.
question: A passive heat exchanger that cools a device by dissipating heat into a fluid medium.

context: A heat pipe is a heat-transfer device that combines the principles of both thermal conductivity and phase transition to eﬀectively transfer heat between two solid interfaces.
question: A heat-transfer device that uses phase transition to move heat efficiently.

context: A Stirling engine is a heat engine that is operated by cyclic compression and expansion of air or other gas (the working ﬂuid) at diﬀerent temperatures, such that there is a net conversion of heat energy to mechanical work.
question: An external combustion engine that operates by cyclic compression and expansion of a gas.

context: A steam engine is a heat engine that performs mechanical work using steam as its working ﬂuid.
question: A heat engine that uses steam as its working fluid.

context: A Rankine cycle is an idealized thermodynamic cycle describing the process by which certain heat engines, such as steam turbines or reciprocating steam engines, allow mechanical work to be extracted from a ﬂuid as it moves between a heat source and heat sink.
question: An idealized thermodynamic cycle that describes how steam engines work.

context: An Otto cycle is an idealized thermodynamic cycle that describes the functioning of a typical spark ignition piston engine.
question: An idealized thermodynamic cycle for spark-ignition internal combustion engines.

context: A Diesel cycle is a combustion process of a reciprocating internal combustion engine. In it, fuel is ignited by heat generated during the compression of air in the combustion chamber, into which fuel is then injected.
question: An idealized thermodynamic cycle for compression-ignition internal combustion engines.

context: A Brayton cycle is a thermodynamic cycle that describes the workings of a constant-pressure heat engine. Gas turbines and airbreathing jet engines use the Brayton cycle.
question: The thermodynamic cycle that describes the workings of gas turbines and jet engines.

context: A Carnot cycle is a theoretical thermodynamic cycle proposed by Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot in 1824 and expanded upon by others in the 1830s and 1840s. It provides an upper limit on the eﬃciency that any classical thermodynamic engine can achieve during the conversion of heat into work.
question: A theoretical thermodynamic cycle that provides the maximum possible efficiency for a heat engine.

context: Eﬃciency is the (often measurable) ability to avoid wasting materials, energy, eﬀorts, money, and time in doing something or in producing a desired result.
question: The ratio of useful work performed by a machine to the total energy expended.

context: Power is the rate of doing work or of transferring heat, i.e. the amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time.
question: The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.

context: Work, in physics, is the energy transferred to or from an object via the application of force along a displacement.
question: The energy transferred to an object by applying a force over a distance.

context: Energy is the quantitative property that must be transferred to an object in order to perform work on, or to heat, the object.
question: The capacity to do work.

context: Kinetic energy is the energy that an object possesses due to its motion.
question: The energy of motion.

context: Potential energy is the energy held by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.
question: Stored energy based on an object's position or state.

context: A gauge is an instrument or device for measuring the magnitude, amount, or contents of something, typically with a visual display.
question: A device for measuring and displaying a quantity.

context: A manometer is a device to measure pressure.
question: A device used to measure pressure, often using a column of liquid.

context: A barometer is a scientiﬁc instrument that is used to measure air pressure in a certain environment.
question: An instrument used to measure atmospheric pressure.

context: A pitot tube is a pressure measurement instrument used to measure ﬂuid ﬂow velocity.
question: An instrument used to measure fluid flow velocity.

context: A venturi meter is a device used for measuring the rate of a ﬂuid ﬂowing through a pipe.
question: A device that measures fluid flow rate by constricting the flow.

context: An oriﬁce plate is a device used for measuring ﬂow rate, for reducing pressure or for restricting ﬂow.

context: A valve is a device or natural object that regulates, directs or controls the ﬂow of a ﬂuid (gases, liquids, ﬂuidized solids, or slurries) by opening, closing, or partially obstructing various passageways.

context: A gasket is a mechanical seal which ﬁlls the space between two or more mating surfaces, generally to prevent leakage from or into the joined objects while under compression.

context: A fastener is a hardware device that mechanically joins or aﬃxes two or more objects together.
question: A hardware device that joins two or more objects together, like a screw or bolt.

context: A screw is a type of fastener, in some ways similar to a bolt, typically made of metal, and characterized by a helical ridge, known as a male thread.
